Headline: headlines
News: Ford declares a state of emergency in Ontario while ordering some business to be closed, including daycares, bars and restaurants, theatres and private schools.

Headline: headlines
News: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces an agreement between Canada and the U.S. restricting all non-essential travel across the border.

Headline: headlines
News: A 51-year-old Milton man becomes the second person to die of COVID-19 in Ontario. It is believed he caught the virus through local transmission.

Headline: headlines
News: The Ontario Ministry of Environment, Conservation and Parks shutters provincial parks until April 30 to protect the health of employees and visitors.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario health officials say there are 43 new cases of the novel coronavirus. The provincial total now jumps to 250 active cases.

Headline: headlines
News: An outbreak is declared at Pinecrest Nursing Home in Bobcaygeon. By April 9, 29 residents, along with a spouse of a resident, would die of COVID-19 complications. The scene would be repeated at long-term care homes across the province.

Headline: headlines
News: Ford orders the closure of all non-essential businesses across the province for 14 days. Some are surprised when the list of businesses to close does not include liquor stores, construction projects and realty services.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario health officials confirm 85 new COVID-19 cases and two more deaths, bringing the provincial total to 572 active cases. Eight people have died from the virus, while eight others have been cleared.

Headline: headlines
News: The Ford government issues an emergency alert to people’s phones in an attempt to warn recent travellers to self-isolate for 14 days.

Headline: headlines
News: The province orders the shutdown of all outdoor amenities while also extending the emergency order through April 12.

Headline: headlines
News: The province announces that Ontario schools will remain closed until at least May.

Headline: headlines
News: The province releases its first projections, saying there could be just under 1,600 COVID-19 deaths and 80,000 cases by the end of April if the current measures in place are upheld. The province also extends the list of non-essential businesses that must close, including non-critical industrial construction projects. Metrolinx, which manages transit in the Greater Toronto and Hamilton Area, announces further reduced service for GO Transit after a 90 per cent drop in ridership.

Headline: headlines
News: The first COVID-19 case surfaces in a northwestern Ontario Indigenous community, prompting calls for a military hospital to be set up.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 550 new cases of the novel coronavirus and 21 more deaths, bringing the provincial totals to 5,276 cases and 174 deaths. Provincial officials also report that 2,074 patients have recovered from the virus.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario orders grocery stores and pharmacies to be closed on Friday and Sunday of the holiday weekend across the province in an effort to ensure employees get a breather.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario extends the state of emergency for another four weeks and pledges further resources to long-term care homes, which have become the epicentre of the crisis in the province.

Headline: headlines
News: Provincial officials report 485 new cases and 36 new deaths, bringing provincial totals to 10,010 and 514, respectively.

Headline: headlines
News: The Ontario government releases the latest modelling, which shows that community spread may have peaked across the province, but officials also warn that numbers continue to grow in long-term care homes, retirement homes and other congregate settings.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford confirms his mother-in-law, who is a resident of a Toronto long-term care home, has tested positive for COVID-19.

Headline: headlines
News: Education Minister Stephen Lecce announces that publicly funded schools will be closed until at least May 31.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford provides the framework in which he will reopen the province although he does not commit  to a date for when it will get underway.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 525 new cases of the novel coronavirus bringing the provincial total to 15,381 cases. A total of 8,964 people have also recovered from COVID-19, the disease caused by the virus, which is 58.3 per cent of cases.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government announces that some seasonal businesses (including nurseries) and some essential construction projects can open on May 4 if they follow strict guidelines.

Headline: headlines
News: Emergency orders are extended by the province for the third time. They will now continue until May 19, which will extend them past Victoria Day weekend.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government announces that beginning on May 9, it will allow garden centres and nurseries to open. A day later, hardware and safety supply stores can open. The following Monday, retail stores with a street entrance will be allowed to provide curbside pick up and delivery only.

Headline: headlines
News: Province announces that beginning on May 11, residents are allowed to walk, hike, bike and bird watch in provincial parks. Camping and access to beaches will remain closed.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 294 new cases of the novel coronavirus, bringing the total number of cases in the province to 20,238. The 294 cases are the lowest increase daily increase announced since March 31.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford provides details on the province’s first stage of its “Phase 2: Restart.” Some businesses are allowed to open on May 16 including campgrounds, marinas and golf courses. A lengthy list of other businesses will be allowed to get underway the following Tuesday.

Headline: headlines
News: The Ontario government says an in-class school year will not be able to recommence during the coronavirus pandemic, however, online learning will continue.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 412 new cases of novel coronavirus, bringing the total number of cases in the province to 25,040.

Headline: headlines
News: Thousands of people gather in Trinity Bellwoods Park in Toronto drawing condemnation and scorn from elected officials and city staff.

Headline: headlines
News: Canadian Armed Forces teams deployed to five of the province’s worst-hit long-term care homes to help control COVID-19 raise concerns about each facility, describing the care as ranging from below best practices to “borderline abusive, if not abusive” and worse, documents obtained by Global News show.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government says it is extending all current emergency orders until June 9.

Headline: headlines
News: Province announces that chiropractors, dentists, massage therapists, optometrists, homeopaths and psychologists can see patients once each profession gets the go-ahead and receives guidelines from each respective governing authority.

Headline: headlines
News: New rules come into effect at Pearson Airport in Mississauga which include mandatory face masks and the barring of “meeters and greeters” from inside its terminals.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario’s state of emergency extended by 28 days but Premier Doug Ford insists that does not mean the province’s reopening will necessarily be put “on hold” during that time.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario allows short-term rentals to operate including lodges, cabins, cottages, homes and condominiums.

Headline: headlines
News: The total number of cases in Ontario passes 30,000 as the province announces 455 new cases including 68 from a reporting delay. A total of 2,407 Ontarians have now suffered COVID-19-related deaths.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario extends emergency orders by another 10 days.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario announces that some regions of the province will enter Stage 2 of its COVID-19 recovery plan. Toronto, Mississauga and Hamilton are among the areas which are excluded.

Headline: headlines
News: Province announces daycares can open the following Friday although few, if any, are able to given the short notice and lengthy set of adjustments needed.

Headline: headlines
News: Province announces “cautious” restart plan to allow visitors back into the province’s long-term care homes beginning June 18.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario announces it has conducted it has now conducted more than a million tests for the novel coronavirus.

Headline: headlines
News: Province announces that several regions including Durham, York, Hamilton, Sarnia-Lambton and Niagara are allowed to enter into Stage 2 of its recovery plan. Toronto, Peel and Windsor remain in Phase 1 however.

Headline: headlines
News: The Ontario government extends all current emergency orders until June 30 while stating it will review each order on a case-by-case basis to determine if it can be adjusted or lifted.

Headline: headlines
News: Toronto and Peel Region permitted to enter Stage 2 of the province’s recovery plan. Windsor-Essex remains alone in Stage 1.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports first death of someone 19 years old or younger. Province does not indicate the exact age or gender of the deceased or where the person is from in Ontario.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government extends emergency orders until July 15.

Headline: headlines
News: Most of the region of Windsor-Essex will be allowed to move into Stage 2. of Ontario’s recovery plan. Leamington and Kingsville left in Stage 1.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 157 new cases of the novel, bringing the provincial total to 35,068. The death toll in the province reaches 2,672.

Headline: headlines
News: Province asks school boards to consider starting the school year earlier than normal.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford announces Kingsville and Leamington, Ont., will move to Stage 2 the following day. The entire province is now in Stage 2.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government extends emergency orders until July 22.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario announces some of the province will enter Stage 3 of the second phase of its recovery plan on July 17. The Greater Toronto Area, Hamilton, Niagara, Haldimand-Norfolk, Lambton and Windsor-Essex are left in Stage 2.

Headline: headlines
News: The province most emergency orders until July 29. The Ford government claims that by doing so, it will allow the government flexibility to ensure vulnerable populations are protected.

Headline: headlines
News: Hamilton, the regions of York, Durham, Halton and Niagara as well as the counties of Haldimand, Horfolk and Lambton are allowed to enter Stage 3 of the province’s reopening plan.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government says Toronto and Peel Region can finally move into Stage 3 of the province’s reopening plan on July 31.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government says come September, elementary students will be in the classroom five days a week while most secondary students will be in at least 50 per cent of the time.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 79 new cases of the novel coronavirus, bringing the total number of cases in the province to 40,046.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government gives Windsor-Essex the green light to move into Stage 3 of the province’s reopening plan on Aug. 12.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government announces it is increasing the number of people indoor sports, fitness and recreation facilities can have, so long as distancing measures are adhered to.

Headline: headlines
News: Ford government announces it is extending the emergency pandemic orders until Sept. 22. The government says the extensions give it the ability to address ongoing risks and effects of the virus and to ensure measures remain in place to protect the population.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government releases 21 page document on how to deal with outbreaks in schools as students and staff close on a return to school.

Headline: headlines
News: Health Minister Christine Elliott announces a pause in loosening any more restrictions that have been put in place due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: headlines
News: A coronavirus outbreak is declared after three Western University students tested positive on Saturday.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 251 new cases of the novel coronavirus, bringing the provincial total to 45,068.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford reduces the number of people allowed at private gathering limits to 10 indoors and 25 outdoors in Toronto, Peel Region and Ottawa. Two days later, they would be expanded across the province.

Headline: headlines
News: Health Minister Christine Elliott announces the province has conducted more than 40,000 tests in a 24-hour period.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario government announces pharmacies in select locations will begin offering COVID-19 tests to people who aren’t experiencing symptoms of the virus as part of its fall preparedness plan.

Headline: headlines
News: The province orders strip clubs to close while also ordering restaurants, bars   and other food and drink businesses to stop serving alcohol at 11 p.m and close between midnight and 5 a.m.

Headline: headlines
News: Pharmacies in the GTA, Huntsville and Ottawa areas begin to offer coronavirus testing to at-risk, asymptomatic people by appointment only.

Headline: headlines
News: Huge crowds take over the Town of Wasaga Beach for a car rally despite provincial gathering restrictions amid the coronavirus pandemic. Images posted to social media show huge crowds lining the streets and cars performing stunt.

Headline: headlines
News: Western University in London, Ont., says at least 28 of its students have tested positive for the coronavirus.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 700 new cases of the novel coronavirus on Monday, marking a new record for the most daily infections ever recorded in the province. It breaks the previous high which was established in April. This also pushes the total number of cases past the 50,000 mark.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford says the province is now officially in the second wave of the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario Hospital Association (OHA) calls on province to return to Phase 2 of its pandemic recovery plan.

Headline: headlines
News: Canada signs deal to buy up to 7.9 million rapid coronavirus rapid point of care tests, pending approval from health officials.

Headline: headlines
News: Durham Public Health reports that at least eight people associated with a wedding in Oshawa have COVID-19.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario health officials say the province could see upwards of 1,000  coronavirus cases a day in October, as the second wave is in full swing.

Headline: headlines
News: Province announces new screening guidelines for daycares and schools which include students only being required to stay home for 24 hours for symptoms such as runny noses.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario announces province-wide mask policy as well as restrictions on number of patrons in bars, restaurants, nightclubs, Banquet halls, event spaces and gyms.

Headline: headlines
News: New restrictions placed on restaurants, bars, banquet halls and gyms in Ottawa, Toronto and Peel Region.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford rejects calls for indoor dining to be ordered closed at restaurants in some areas of the province amid rising coronavirus cases, saying there isn’t enough evidence to make such a decision.

Headline: headlines
News: Christopher Saccoccia, also known as Chris Sky, and 34-year-old Jennifer Saccoccia were both charged with failure to comply with an order prohibiting or subjecting to any condition the entry into Canada.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 548 new cases of the novel coronavirus, bringing the provincial total to 55,362.

Headline: headlines
News: The province reports 797 new cases of the novel coronavirus. The province processed nearly 48,500 tests, is also a new provincial record.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario is reporting 939 new cases of coronavirus. For the second day in a row, the province reports a record number of news cases.

Headline: headlines
News: New restrictions are put in place for Toronto, Peel Region and Ottawa amid rising coronavirus cases including the closure of indoor dining at restaurants and bars, as well as the closure of gyms, casinos, cinemas, and performing arts centres.

Headline: headlines
News: Seven new COVID-19-related deaths are announced, bringing the provincial death toll to 3,004.

Headline: headlines
News: Hamilton public health officials link 47 cases to an outbreak at a spin studio in the city. Thirty-eight are considered primary (36 members and 2 employees) and nine secondary.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 746 new positive tests for the coronavirus. The total cumulative number of cases reaches 60,692.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 704 new cases of coronavirus, bringing the provincial total to 65,075.

Headline: headlines
News: Independent MPP Randy Hillier hosts a gathering of over 25 people in which most were not wearing masks. No fines are laid.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario’s independent commission into long-term care releases early recommendations for the Ford government to implement during the second wave of the pandemic. In addition, it says that during the first wave, 55 per cent of long-term care homes in the province reported an outbreak, while 75 per cent of all deaths were represented by long-term care residents.

Headline: headlines
News: A 21-year-old man dies after being shot in a parking lot outside an east-end LCBO following an argument inside the store. The LCBO employee’s union confirms the dispute was over social distancing.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports over 1,000 new cases of COVID-19 for the first time. The province announces 1,042 new cases, bringing the total number of cases in the province to 70,373.

Headline: headlines
News: GoodLife Fitness sends an email to 175,000 people urging them to lobby Ontario MPPs as the province begins to close them in the wake of a rising tide of new COVID-19 cases.

Headline: headlines
News: Premier Doug Ford’s constituency office in Etobicoke confirms a COVID-19 outbreak.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 1,015 new cases of the novel coronavirus, bringing the total number of cases across the province to 75,730.

Headline: headlines
News: The province introduces a new five-tiered, colour-coded system for determining how it will regulate areas when during the COVID-19 pandemic. The following levels were used: Prevent (standard measures — green), protect (strengthened measures — yellow), restrict (intermediate measures — orange), control (stringent measures — red), and lockdown (maximum measures — grey).

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 998 new cases of coronavirus, bringing the provincial total to 80,690.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario releases an updated list of which areas are placed in which zones in its new coronavirus system. Peel is alone in the red zone while Ottawa and York Region were placed in the orange zone and several others including Waterloo and Guelph were moved to yellow.

Headline: headlines
News: The province reports 1,242 new cases of coronavirus, bringing the provincial total to 85,395.

Headline: headlines
News: It is announced that Toronto will enter the red zone under Ontario’s recently-introduced coronavirus system in the days that follow.

Headline: headlines
News: The province reports 1,575 new cases of coronavirus, a new record and also the first time Ontario has reported more than 1,500 cases in one day.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 1,487 new cases of coronavirus, bringing the provincial total to 95,496. This is the 11th straight day the province has announced more than 1,000 new cases.

Headline: headlines
News: A day after the provincial government says it is considering a prolonged winter break, it nixes the idea with Education Minister Stephen Lecce saying it is “not necessary” because current protocols are working.

Headline: headlines
News: It is announced that a child and youth worker at a Toronto school has died after contracting COVID-19.  The woman worked at St. Francis De Sales Catholic School.

Headline: headlines
News: The Ford government announces it will extend current orders under the Reopening Ontario Act until Dec. 21 due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 1,418 new cases of coronavirus, as the province surpasses 100,000 cumulative cases, bringing the provincial total to 100,790.

Headline: headlines
News: Adam Skelly, who owns Adamson Barbecue, is arrested after opening his restaurant for indoor dining, ignoring COVID-19 restrictions put in place by the province.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reports 1,859 new cases of the novel coronavirus, bringing the total number of cases in the province to 125,385.

Headline: headlines
News: The province reports 1,924 new cases of the coronavirus, bringing the total number of cases in the province to 127,309. This is a record number of new cases and the first time the province has announced more than 1,900 new cases in one day.

Headline: headlines
News: Doug Ford lays out his government’s three-part vaccination rollout plan. Vulnerable seniors, their caregivers, and health-care workers are among those who will get it first

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario’s fiscal watchdog says the province had $12 billion in unspent reserve funds by the end of September.

Headline: headlines
News: Health Minister Christine Elliott says residents who get a COVID-19 vaccine will be issued proof they received a shot which may be necessary to avoid some restrictions.

Headline: headlines
News: Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine is officially approved for use in Canada, with limited rollout set to begin to priority groups “within days.”

Headline: headlines
News: York Region and Windsor-Essex will move into lockdown under Ontario’s COVID-19 colour-coded system, joining Toronto and Peel Region.

Headline: headlines
News: A Peterborough man who spent more than eight months at Peterborough Regional Health Centre fighting COVID-19  is discharged from hospital.

Headline: headlines
News: The Ford government announces that COVID-19 tests will no longer be free for people requiring proof of a negative test for international travel destinations.

Headline: headlines
News: Anita Quidangen, a personal support worker, is first to receive Pfizer’s vaccine in Toronto, with  four other long-term care workers vaccinated soon after.

Headline: headlines
News: Ontario reported 2,275 new cases of coronavirus, marking a new single-day record. Health Minister Christine Elliott says the increase in cases is in part due to a lengthened period of data collection.
